titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the W. E. Hook Photographs of Colorado, New Mexico, and Texas
Hook (W. E.) Photographs of Colorado, New Mexico, and Texas
titlestmt.author: by Matthew Daniel Mason

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 22, 2019 at 07:24

did.unittitle: W. E. Hook photographs of Colorado, New Mexico, and Texas.

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.physdesc: (2 boxes)
did.abstract: Photographs collected by the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library that document the photography of W. E. Hook, 1885-1908. The collection chiefly includes photographs of sites in Colorado, as well as some images of New Mexico and Texas. Photographs in the collection document the different presentation methods used by Hook to market his images, including cabinet photographs, as well as the variant titles he used in negatives and on photographic mounts.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Acquired by gift and purchase. For more information see the finding aid.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The W. E. Hook Photographs of Colorado, New Mexico, and Texas is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: W. E. Hook Photographs of Colorado, New Mexico, and Texas. Yale Collection of Western Americana, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.
Former call number: WA Photos File

bioghist.head: W. E. Hook (1833-1908)
bioghist.p: William Edward Hook (1833-1908) was born in Litchfield, England. His family immigrated briefly to the United States in 1834, but returned to England by 1851. In 1857, he married Eleanor Jane Dore (circa 1833-1914) and they had six children.

In 1867, Hook returned to the United States without his family. Two years later he established a photography studio in Chippewa Falls, Wisconsin. In February 1875, two of his sons joined him in the United States: Theodore Hook (circa 1859-circa 1875) and William Edward Hook, Jr. (circa 1864-1907).

In 1877, Hook closed his photography studio in Wisconsin, and he and his surviving son, William, worked as traveling photographers from a home base in Missoula, Montana. Over the next four years, they travelled and captured images throughout Montana and Wyoming, including Yellowstone National Park, Alberta, Northwest Territory, and the Canadian Northwest Rockies. By 1881, Hook established a photography studio in Marquette, Michigan, from which he marketed his images of the American West.

In April 1885, Hook established a photography studio in Manitou Springs, Colorado. In September 1885, he filed a homestead claim on the nearby Ruxton Creek near Pikes Peak, which he named "Artist's Glen." Over the years, Hook specialized in marketing landscape views of Colorado to tourists.

In 1887, Hook traveled to England. He returned to Colorado with his wife and their daughters, Eleanor "Nellie" Hook (born circa 1858) and Alice M. Hook (born circa 1864, later Mrs. Edward M. De La Vergne); their son, William also rejoined the family. Over the years, the Hook family filed additional homestead claims around Ruxton Creek. They also operated a boarding house for tourists until 1890, when the construction and operations associated with the Manitou and Pike's Peak Railway – a steep grade railway from Manitou Springs to the summit of Pikes Peak – prompted the family to relocate to Colorado Springs. Hook then operated a photography studio in Colorado Springs until his death from heart failure.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs collected by the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library that document the photography of W. E. Hook, 1885-1908. The collection chiefly includes photographs of sites in Colorado, as well as some images of New Mexico and Texas. Photographs in the collection document the different presentation methods used by Hook to market his images, including cabinet photographs, as well as the variant titles he used in negatives and on photographic mounts.

Images of sites in Colorado include Cascade Canyon, Cheyenne Mountain, Colorado Springs, Garden of the Gods, Leadville, Manitou Springs, Mount of the Holy Cross, North Cheyenne Canyon, Pikes Peak, Royal Gorge, South Cheyenne Canyon, Ute Pass, and Williams Canyon. An exterior group portrait of Ute Indians in Colorado includes Chief Sapiah, also known as Buckskin Charlie. Images of New Mexico consist of an overview of Santa Fe and an exterior group portrait of Tewa Indians at the Tesuque Pueblo. The collection also includes a view of the Franklin School in El Paso, Texas.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into one series: I. Photographs, 1885-1908.

did.unittitle: Photographs

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is organized into three subseries: Colorado, New Mexico, and Texas

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs that chiefly document sites in Colorado, as well as New Mexico and Texas

did.unittitle: Colorado
Cascade Canyon
View of Peek-A-Boo Falls in Cascade Canyon near Cascade, Colorado, with a woman posed sitting on a boulder
did.physdesc: 18.5 x 11.2 cm on mount 20.2 x 12.7 cm

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Printed in negative: "Peek-a-Boo Falls, Cascade Colo., 454"
Blindstamp on recto: "The W. E. Hook Wholesale View Co., Colorado Springs, Colo."

did.unittitle: Cheyenne Mountain
View of the grave site of Helen (Fiske) Hunt Jackson on Cheyenne Mountain, Colorado.
did.physdesc: 11.1 x 18.4 cm on mount 12.7 x 20.3 cm

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Image shows a large pile of stones, a cairn, which marks the grave in a forest.
Printed in negative: "Hook Photo, 202 Grave Mrs. Jackson. (H. H.) Cheyenne Mountain"
Blindstamp on recto: "The W. E. Hook Wholesale View Co., Colorado Springs, Colo."
Inscription on verso: "F. F."

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Thomas C. Klopp on the Arthur Corbitt Hoskins Memorial Fund, 2013

did.unittitle: Colorado Springs
View of the Broadmoor Casino in Colorado Springs, Colorado
did.physdesc: 10.7 x 18.4 cm on mount 12.7 x 20.3 cm

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: View of the casino, a two-story frame building with a colonnaded, pedimented entry, and balustrades, as well as a wrap-around porch and balcony. Its lawn has a pavilion and planted flower letters that form "Broadmoor"
Printed in negative: "Hook Photo"
Blindstamp on recto: "The W. E. Hook Wholesale View Co., Colorado Springs, Col."

did.unittitle: Garden of the Gods
View of Balanced Rock, a rock formation at Garden of the Gods near Colorado Springs, Colorado
did.physdesc: 18.9 x 11.3 cm on mount 20.3 x 12.7 cm

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Image shows a large sandstone boulder balanced on a rock ledge
Printed in negative: "Hook Photo, 115 Balanced Rock, Garden of the Gods"
Ink stamp on verso: "509 N. Tejon St., Colorado Springs, Colorado., W. E. Hook, view and portrait photographer, Colorado Wholesale View House"

did.unittitle: Unidentified Locations
Exterior group portrait of Ute Indian men, women, children, and a baby, as well as European American men.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The portrait includes Chief Sapiah (circa 1840-1936), also known as Charles Buck or Buckskin Charlie, posed standing with fur wrapped braids, a hairpipe breastplate, concho belt and a feather in his hair. The Ute Indian men wear hair pipe breastplates, beaded sashes, printed fabric, conchos, leggings, moccasins and feather headdresses, roaches, and or feathers. The women wear beaded or quilled buckskin dresses. Children play with toys on woven blankets by a baby in a cradleboard decorated with beadwork and quillwork.
Printed in negative: "Copyright, Hook Photo, 1681, Chief Buckskin Charlie and Band of Ute Indians"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Inscription on verso: "Hook (Colorado), Chief Buckskin Charlie and his band of Ute Indians. Note Indian with glasses"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Blindstamp on recto: "The W. E. Hook Wholesale View Co., Colorado Springs, Colo."
Inscription on verso recounting a mountain trip by an unidentified female tourist mounted on the donkey through South Cheyenne Canyon and over Cheyenne Mountain on August 2, 1894
